channel.title: Scrypt
channel.description:
What do you guys think about this? I think it looks good.

item.title: Scrypt
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“wildskiller, post:23, topic:547254”][quote author=RSCShadow link=topic=666160.msg4453713#msg4453713 date=1413318444]

Why is it that people are trying to find better ways to encrypt messages when shifting a sequence by a randomly generated key is enough. You have like a 1/1000 trillion million chance to find the key to decode the message.

Also, maybe if the key has been used a certain amount of times, the key could be shuffled.
[/quote]We aren’t finding better ways to encrypt messages, we’re trying to find better ways to store passwords. Encryption implies decryption, which is not something one wishes to do when storing passwords.

Well, how could using password security be better than a private algorithmic encoding? Taking more time to decode shouldn’t be an excuse.[/quote]You can’t decode a hash. That’s the point; it’s one way. Now just because you can’t just follow an algorithm to decode it back to its original form doesn’t mean that it’s not possible to find the original input.

If I have an MD5 and I wish to find what input was used to create it, it would be trivial to test millions of passwords in a very short amount of time. This time’s cut even shorter when you can use multiple GPUs spread across multiple machines. Even if you added a salt, all it does is increase the amount of passwords to try (and when you have a beefy enough machine, it will make little to no impact).

With something like bcrypt, the idea is to have the amount of time it takes to compute be adjustable, and not capable of being performed faster using special hardware (like GPUs). Doing this adds the extra security of not being able to calculate hundreds of hashes within milliseconds.

The point is even if there are trillions of possibilities, if you can test them all extremely quickly then it’s not as secure.

And in case you aren’t familiar where passwords are used, think about how you logged into this website.

Read full topic

item.title: Scrypt
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

Justin Bieber:

the kid was talking about encryption not hashing, so i was responding to him. would you care to explain why you used the word encryption in response to my message, even though this is a topic about hashing?

Fair enough.

Justin Bieber:

rsa and other asymmetric methods of encryption are considered bad compared to the magical best-case methods wildskiller refers too (i’m assuming he’s describing one time pads)

OTPs are hardly as useful as RSA or other asymmetric schemes because the key must be as long as the text, can only be used once, and must remain completely secret.

Read full topic

item.title: Scrypt
item.dc:creator: @wildskiller wildskiller
item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:21, topic:547254”][quote author=wildskiller link=topic=666160.msg4453689#msg4453689 date=1413306363]
Why is it that people are trying to find better ways to encrypt messages when shifting a sequence by a randomly generated key is enough. You have like a 1/1000 trillion million chance to find the key to decode the message.

Also, maybe if the key has been used a certain amount of times, the key could be shuffled.
[/quote]We aren’t finding better ways to encrypt messages, we’re trying to find better ways to store passwords. Encryption implies decryption, which is not something one wishes to do when storing passwords.[/quote]
Well, how could using password security be better than a private algorithmic encoding? Taking more time to decode shouldn’t be an excuse.

Justin Bieber:

the kid was talking about encryption not hashing, so i was responding to him. would you care to explain why you used the word encryption in response to my message, even though this is a topic about hashing? rsa and other asymmetric methods of encryption are considered bad compared to the magical best-case methods wildskiller refers too (i’m assuming he’s describing one time pads)

I was talking about the one-time pad, but I was just making a point; although off-topic. If you want a secure file, you wouldn’t need a password, you would just create key to shift the bytes of the file. I believe it’s easier to break through a password than an encrypted file.

I don’t understand why using passwords would be a better alternative. I’ve never used a password, so I guess my opinion of this couldn’t be relative.

Read full topic

item.title: Scrypt
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:12, topic:547254”][quote author=justaguy link=topic=666160.msg4453626#msg4453626 date=1413255139]

A password-based key derivation function (password-based KDF) is generally designed to be computationally intensive, so that it takes a relatively long time to compute (say on the order of several hundred milliseconds).

sounds like a lousy way of making something secure.

lmfao

what’s so funny? it’s much more likely that that one could compute an algorithm faster than store all permutations to produce an effective rainbow table for something like SHA 512.

Well the point of something like scrypt is that to actually generate your hashes it has to make these long computations in the first place. You can’t just compute an algorithm to make it “go faster.” The reason it is intensive like it is because it’s not only resistant to Moore’s Law but also to custom hardware attacks. If a hacker compromised your database, the time it would take to try and make a rainbow table would be just as tedious (if not, more?) than SHA since the latter is fast to compute.

I don’t disagree that SHA-256+ is secure, I just disagree with your statement that it’s “lousy.”
[/quote]
By speeding up execution I mean utilizing more/faster memory as the algorithm demands, if I recall scrypt came about in response to bcrypt’s weakness against FPGA attacks. Wouldn’t scrypt share the same weakness just at a different scale?[/quote]

scrypt techinically would share the same weakness but it now has exponential memory usage while bcrypt didn’t. I haven’t done much research into this sort of attack but this is exactly the reason scrypt was designed and so I imagine the author was able to figure out that the amount of memory required for this algorithm is too much for any cost-effective hardware; not to mention its memory usage is variable.

Read full topic

A password-based key derivation function (password-based KDF) is generally designed to be computationally intensive, so that it takes a relatively long time to compute (say on the order of several hundred milliseconds).

sounds like a lousy way of making something secure.

lmfao

what’s so funny? it’s much more likely that that one could compute an algorithm faster than store all permutations to produce an effective rainbow table for something like SHA 512.
[/quote]

Well the point of something like scrypt is that to actually generate your hashes it has to make these long computations in the first place. You can’t just compute an algorithm to make it “go faster.” The reason it is intensive like it is because it’s not only resistant to Moore’s Law but also to custom hardware attacks. If a hacker compromised your database, the time it would take to try and make a rainbow table would be just as tedious (if not, more?) than SHA since the latter is fast to compute.

I don’t disagree that SHA-256+ is secure, I just disagree with your statement that it’s “lousy.”[/quote]
By speeding up execution I mean utilizing more/faster memory as the algorithm demands, if I recall scrypt came about in response to bcrypt’s weakness against FPGA attacks. Wouldn’t scrypt share the same weakness just at a different scale?

Well the point of something like scrypt is that to actually generate your hashes it has to make these long computations in the first place. If a hacker compromised your database, the time it would take to try and make a rainbow table would be just as tedious (if not, more?) than SHA since the latter is fast to compute.

item.title: Scrypt
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

[quote=“Ashi, post:5, topic:547254”][quote author=Whackatre link=topic=666160.msg4453598#msg4453598 date=1413248638]
hi i’m ashi and welcome to another episode of “hey guys what do you think of [current hipster trend/outdated hipster trend that i just discovered (prolly on /g/ or leddit xd xd)] how cool is that guys i’m gonna start writing software with it SO WHT IS YOUR OPINION”

but really honestly who cares as long as your hash function is slow as fudge and usable and convenient you will be fine for most cases now go write code
[/quote]
I could eat a bowl of alphabet soup and shit out a smarter statement than that.[/quote]

well at least i’m not a dumb 300 lb basement-dweller neckbeard hipster with a gender identity crisis, who raves and posts almost daily about all the neat little modern (actually you’re a little old) hipster1sms (and not even!) he finds, and then proceeds to chide people for calling him out on his shit. use bcrypt/scrypt or whatever the fudge that works, hell, even the higher-order shas; both of those are nice. posting dumb, laughable questions with no real purpose is a surefire way to to get replies that are just as bad. if you don’t have anything to add, other than “how’s dis guise???”, then you might as well just leave us alone (till now) and google. i don’t know if scrypt is hugely widely implemented but from misterhat’s post i’m not too sure about its prevalence (but i have faith that it gets around, since scrypt is actually not unknown.) so if you find it, and you like it, then use it. basically yea, bcrypt is good enough already, but if you want the memory-huge scrypt (which is great and better than bcrypt, theoretically, in the case of an event such as a db leak) then go for it.

also i believe my nice friend justaguy has posted about this before. search, go, and bye. :rolleyes: ;D :o

Read full topic

item.title: Scrypt
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

RSCShadow:

Interesting. According to the trendy blog articles I read, the amount of memory as well as computational expense is adjustable compared to bcrypt where only the computational expense can be changed. Hopefully implementing it is just as convenient or it’ll never take off.

https://github.com/wg/scrypt

Read full topic
